title: Newly Published, From James Baldwin to a Life-Changing Dog
description: A selection of books published this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo, Richard Pérez-Peña and Ruth Graham
title: Pope Weighs In on Calls to Deny Communion to Biden Over Abortion
description: “What must the pastor do?” Francis said when a reporter asked him about the subject. “Be a pastor, don’t go condemning.”
content: ROME — Pope Francis weighed in on Wednesday on a debate roiling the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, where conservative bishops are pushing for guidelines that would deny communion to politicians, like President Biden, who support abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Cabinet Reshuffle a Blow to Boris Johnson’s Global Ambitions
description: The prime minister reassigned the foreign minister, Dominic Raab, after the messy exit from Afghanistan, a setback for a government seeking a greater role on the world stage.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson demoted his foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, on Wednesday in a sweeping cabinet shake-up that made Britain’s chief diplomat a highly visible casualty of the West’s chaotic exit from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Alex Murdaugh to Surrender for Staging His Own Killing
description: The police have opened a separate inquiry into the death of a housekeeper at Mr. Murdaugh’s home in 2018, the latest twist in the story of his powerful South Carolina family.
content: Alex Murdaugh, a prominent South Carolina lawyer who is at the center of multiple investigations after his wife and son were shot and killed at the family’s home in June, plans to turn himself in on Thursday on charges that he staged his own assassination, even as he continued to deny any involvement in the killing of his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Adam Goldman, Michael S. Schmidt and William K. Rashbaum
title: Durham Is Said to Seek Indictment of Lawyer at Firm With Democratic Ties
description: The lawyer, Michael Sussmann, is accused of lying to the F.B.I. in a 2016 meeting about Trump and Russia. He denies wrongdoing.
content: WASHINGTON — John H. Durham, the special counsel appointed by the Trump administration to scrutinize the Russia investigation, has told the Justice Department that he will ask a grand jury to indict a prominent cybersecurity lawyer on a charge of making a false statement to the F.B.I., people familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo, Jill Cowan, Jennifer Medina and Miriam Jordan
title: The pandemic was the No. 1 issue for many voters in California’s recall election.
description: The recall served as a preview of next year’s midterm elections, with voters sharply divided over masks, lockdowns and mandatory vaccinations.
content: The coronavirus pandemic helped propel the recall attempt of Gov. Gavin Newsom to the ballot in California, and on Tuesday, his handling of the pandemic was an overriding issue as about two-thirds of voters decided he should stay in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Katy Reckdahl
title: The Greatest Killer in New Orleans Wasn’t the Hurricane. It Was the Heat.
description: A huge power failure after Hurricane Ida left vulnerable residents in sweltering apartments for days. At least 10 deaths in the city have been tied to the heat.
content: NEW ORLEANS — In many ways, Iley Joseph’s one-bedroom apartment was an ideal place to ride out a hurricane. It was on the third floor — much too high to flood — of a building that was sturdy and new, part of a sleek, gated community for older residents like him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Sarah Gillis will be a key voice in the astronauts’ ears as they head to orbit.
description: The engineer trained the astronauts on the Crew Dragon capsule's systems and will also provide key communications on their trip to orbit.
content: As the four amateur astronauts head into space, the voice of Sarah Gillis will guide them into orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Philadelphia to Pay $2 Million to Woman Pulled From S.U.V. During Protest
description: “It’s life-changing money for Rickia and her family,” a lawyer for Rickia Young said. “But what she went through was equally life-changing.”
content: The city of Philadelphia has agreed to pay $2 million to a young Black mother after police officers smashed the windows of the sport utility vehicle she was in, yanked her out and beat her after she inadvertently found herself in a police barricade last fall, the woman’s lawyers said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Hamilton
title: Fall in Love With the Dreamy Beans of September
description: Plump and supple, fresh beans in season have a creamy earthiness.
content: There are dozens of completely different New Year’s Days in the world. As many calendars, too: lunar, fiscal, academic, religious, civil, agrarian, Gregorian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Biles and Her Teammates Rip the F.B.I. for Botching Nassar Abuse Case
description: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, apologized for “inexcusable” failures in the investigation of Lawrence G. Nassar, who sexually abused hundreds of women and girls.
content: WASHINGTON — Sitting at a witness table alongside three of her former gymnastics teammates, Simone Biles broke down in tears while explaining to a Senate committee that she doesn’t want any more young people to experience the kind of suffering she endured at the hands of Lawrence G. Nassar, the former national team doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Soho Rep Returns With Job Initiative and New Plays
description: Sarah Benson, the theater’s artistic director, said she hopes that the productions this season will respond to a transformative moment in theater.
content: It has been nearly two years since Soho Rep has staged a show in its 65-seat theater at 46 Walker Street. And Sarah Benson, the theater’s artistic director since 2007, is in disbelief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Newsom Survives California Recall Vote and Will Remain Governor
description: Voters reaffirmed their landslide support of Gov. Gavin Newsom in 2018.
content: SACRAMENTO — A Republican-led bid to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom of California ended in defeat late Tuesday, as Democrats in the nation’s most populous state closed ranks against a small grass-roots movement that accelerated with the spread of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Covid Referendum
description: California voters rejected the attempt to remove Gov. Gavin Newsom from office.
content: In the run-up to yesterday’s recall election in California, both Gov. Gavin Newsom and his critics framed it as a judgment on his handling of the pandemic. Newsom embraced his enactment of aggressive mask and vaccine mandates. His leading Republican opponent, Larry Elder, promised to cancel those mandates before drinking his first cup of tea on his first day in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: 1,400 Dolphins Were Killed in Faroe Islands. Even Hunting Supporters Were Upset.
description: Graphic images of the animals raised ire among activists, and some locals said the killings undermined the work of whale hunters who follow a centuries-old tradition that helps feed local people.
content: The custom of whale and dolphin hunting, known as grindadrap, is a centuries-old practice in the Faroe Islands and a key part of many locals’ diet. And many Faroese point to regulations — including rules around the killing of mammals — aimed at making the practice sustainable as a reason to keep the tradition alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: Court Overturns Ex-Minneapolis Officer’s Murder Conviction in 2017 Shooting
description: Mohamed Noor’s manslaughter conviction stands, and he will be resentenced on that count in the death of Justine Ruszczyk.
content: Mohamed Noor, a former Minneapolis police officer who in 2017 killed a woman who had called for help at her home, had his third-degree murder conviction thrown out by the Minnesota Supreme Court on Wednesday, an abrupt reversal in a case that drew international attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Huylebroek
title: This Is Life in Rural Afghanistan After the Taliban Takeover
description: Since the Taliban takeover, much of Afghanistan’s countryside has seen a big drop in violence after 20 years of fighting. “It has been a long time now since a bullet hit our homes.”
content: CHAK-E WARDAK, Afghanistan — Sixty bone-rattling miles southwest of Kabul, remnants of America’s longest war are abundant. Pillaged outposts scatter the hilltops, and skeletons of burned-out police pickup trucks and Humvees litter the road that weaves through the valleys in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: With Democrats defecting, a crucial drug pricing proposal in the $3.5 trillion bill failed a key test.
description: The defeat in a House committee came as President Biden was scheduled to meet with two key moderate senators who have balked at the cost of the overall package.
content: A Democratic plan to control prescription drug prices as part of their $3.5 trillion social policy package failed in a House committee on Wednesday after moderates refused to support it, imperiling a crucial element of the measure and a substantial chunk of the revenue needed to finance it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Former Georgetown Tennis Coach Agrees to Plead Guilty in Admissions Scandal
description: Gordon Ernst was accused of taking bribes to designate at least 12 students as recruits, including some who did not play tennis competitively.
content: A former Georgetown University men’s and women’s tennis coach accused of soliciting and accepting bribes to help students get into the university was the latest person to agree to plead guilty Wednesday in an admissions investigation that has touched elite schools across the country, according to the U.S. attorney’s office for the District of Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Announces Defense Deal With Australia in a Bid to Counter China
description: President Biden said the United States and Britain would help Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines, adding to the Western presence in the region.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration took a major step on Wednesday in challenging China’s broad territorial claims in the Pacific, announcing that the United States and Britain would help Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines, adding to the Western presence in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The U.S. Is Winning the War on Poverty
description: Government programs have steadily reduced the share of people in poverty
content: Last year in the United States, poverty either increased or decreased. Take your pick. The poverty rate rose by the Census Bureau’s narrow, official measure, but it fell by the bureau’s supplementary measure, which takes into account a wider range of income and expenses, including pandemic assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A defense deal between Australia, the U.S. and Britain.
content: The U.S. and Britain will share technology to help Australia deploy nuclear-powered submarines that could have a range extending across the Pacific, challenging China’s territorial claims in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: Can’t Find a Franchise Quarterback? Shop for the Best Antidote.
description: N.F.L. teams are in an ever-escalating arms race to generate maximum pressure on opposing quarterbacks. The Steelers pass rusher T.J. Watt and other QB maulers benefit from the demand.
content: If an N.F.L. team does not possess a quarterback of Tom Brady’s or Patrick Mahomes’s caliber, one of the best ways to remain competitive is to load up on pass rushers so its defense can sack opponents into submission. On the other hand, if a team is fortunate enough to employ an elite quarterback, its best chance to win the Super Bowl is to juice up its pass rush to neutralize his counterpart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Lauren Ridloff’s Deafness Became a Superpower in Marvel’s ‘Eternals’
description: In her first major role in a feature film, she wasn’t fazed by things that might unnerve others, but she had to show filmmakers how to work with deafness.
content: The assistant director was concerned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Study of Booster Shot Benefits Fans Debate Over Extra Doses
description: Independent experts, including government scientists, were skeptical of the research from Israel, which included limited data over a short period.
content: Wading into an acrimonious debate over booster doses, researchers in Israel reported on Wednesday that a third dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine can prevent both infections and severe illness in adults older than 60 for at least 12 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Will Districts Mandate Shots for Students?
description: Districts diverge on vaccine mandates.
content: Today, we’re looking at efforts to mandate vaccinations for teachers and students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Sophie Kasakove
title: Nicholas, now a tropical depression, brings heavy rain to the flood-battered South.
description: Forecasters warned that the storm could produce life-threatening flash flooding as it moved east through Louisiana on Wednesday.
content: Tropical Depression Nicholas has unleashed heavy rain across parts of Louisiana this week, raising the risk of severe flooding in an area already battered by Hurricane Ida and still struggling to restore electricity to tens of thousands of customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: You Got Me There
description: Sophie Buchmueller and Ross Trudeau gift us all with juke boxes.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Sophie Buchmueller on making her New York Times Crossword debut, and to Ross Trudeau for his sixth collaboration and 10th puzzle published this year alone (out of 15 collaborations and 44 puzzles total!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The U.S. pandemic outlook.
content: Even if you’ve been following news of the virus closely, it can be hard to know which way the pandemic is headed. To help sort it out, I gathered a few charts that give us a clearer picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina del Valle Schorske
title: Dancing Through New York in a Summer of Joy and Grief
description: During the brief moment when the pandemic was receding and we could be together again, all we wanted to do was move our bodies.
content: For most of 2020, I passed the pandemic alone in my studio apartment. I turned 33, then 34, and my body seemed to grow old without bringing my spirit along with it. My right knee was clearly deteriorating — I couldn’t sit cross-legged at my desk the way I used to — and because I wasn’t wearing makeup, I could track each age spot as it bloomed to the surface. When I pulled my hair back in a tight ponytail, I could see a patch of scalp. But in that same period had my life evolved at all? Had I met anyone? Surprised myself? Stemmed the tide of collective crisis? My mother often urged me to dance, just a little, by myself in the kitchen — “It’s good medicine,” she said, “despojo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
title: The E.U. adopts a new strategy to counter future pandemics.
description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the E.U.’s executive arm, also said the bloc would donate 200 million additional vaccine doses to middle- and low-income countries by mid-2022.
content: The European Union announced on Wednesday the creation of a new biomedical authority designed to better respond to future pandemics, as it seeks to avoid repeating the mistakes that plagued its early response to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: New York Fashion Week Returns. Here’s the Cliffs Notes Version.
description: In case you missed it, a tour through our coverage of the shows.
content: You know something has changed when the biggest celebrity at a fashion show is not Gina Gershon or Nicky Hilton, but Kathy Hochul, the new governor of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Why Is Everyone Talking to Ibai Llanos?
description: A 26-year-old Spanish streamer counts Lionel Messi as an admirer and Gerard Piqué as a business partner. His interviews might be a glimpse into the future of sports media.
content: Outside, in the bright Parisian sunshine, the world’s news media lined up on the edge of the field at the Parc des Princes. Producers fiddled busily with cameras and boom microphones. Reporters chattered away, dutifully filling airtime before their designated interview slots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden to host leaders to discuss climate change ahead of a U.N. summit.
description: In a virtual meeting Friday, Mr. Biden will urge countries to take more ambitious steps to tackle climate change, including curbing methane.
content: President Biden will virtually convene on Friday some of the leaders of the nations most responsible for climate change, urging them to do more to slash greenhouse gas emissions ahead of a critical United Nations summit in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Is Craig Counsell the Best Manager in Baseball?
description: His Brewers could win 100 games and his players can’t believe he’s never won the Manager of the Year Award. That he’s doing it at home in Milwaukee is icing on the cake.
content: MILWAUKEE — The last time the Milwaukee Brewers reached a World Series, Craig Counsell was 12. His father worked for the team, so Counsell would often tag along, including during that 1982 playoff run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Bewilderment,’ Richard Powers Smothers Nature With Piety
description: A grieving astrobiologist bemoans the state of the planet while raising his sensitive 9-year-old son in Powers’s new novel.
content: “The world had enough novels,” Richard Powers wrote in “Galatea 2.2,” his semi-autobiographical and arguably best novel, published in 1995. “Certain writers were best paid to keep their fields out of production.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Defeated in the recall, Larry Elder looks to a future in conservative politics.
description: The California recall turned the conservative talk radio host into a bona fide Trump-era political celebrity.
content: If there was a breakout star of California’s recall election, it was Larry Elder, a conservative talk radio host who, over the course of the spring and summer, turned himself into a bona fide Trump-era political celebrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Nightbooks’ Review: A Fairy Tale Horror Fit for Kids
description: Genuine scares elevate this modern take on Hansel and Gretel, which follows a bright boy who is held captive in an evil witch’s apartment.
content: In the children’s horror movie “Nightbooks,” a preteen boy is held hostage by a malevolent witch. Alex (Winslow Fegley) is a bright kid whose passion lies in writing scary stories. At the start of the movie (on Netflix), Alex renounces the hobby, fearing it makes him a freak show. On his way to burn his notebooks, however, he is lured into the enchanted apartment of Natacha (Krysten Ritter), who threatens to kill Alex unless he spins her a new tale every evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: How New York Is New York Fashion?
description: An infusion of out-of-town talent brings a jolt of energy to Men’s Day at New York Fashion Week.
content: There is a mental game one plays every time New York Fashion Week rolls around, with its frenzy of runway shows, its TikTok moments and those bevies of freshly minted influencers for whom Warhol’s 15 minutes of fame seems like a generous allotment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: With polls still open in California, millions of votes have been received so far.
description: Already, more people have returned ballots than cast votes in the last California recall election in 2003.
content: More than nine million votes have already been received in the California recall election, suggesting a relatively high turnout more reminiscent not of a low-wattage special election but of a high-profile midterm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Grace Ashford
title: 2 Parties, 2 Maps: Democrats and Republicans Squabble on Redistricting
description: Two competing proposals advance, and the failure to compromise may pave the way for Democrats to step in and knock out Republican congressional seats.
content: New York’s new bipartisan redistricting commission got off to an inauspicious start on Wednesday, as its Democratic and Republican members failed to reach an agreement on an initial set of congressional and legislative map proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: To Unseat Trudeau, Canada’s Top Conservative Leans Left
description: Erin O’Toole, the Conservative Party leader, has brought his party into a statistical tie in polls with the Liberals.
content: OTTAWA — The leader of Canada’s Conservative Party, Erin O’Toole, lacks the name recognition, celebrity pedigree and charismatic hair of his Liberal Party rival, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. A former corporate lawyer with nine years of service in the House of Commons, he came into the snap elections campaign new to the leadership of his party, unfamiliar to most Canadians and not especially popular even among many Conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Can a President Do About Wildfires?
description: President Biden touted his actions on wildfires on a tour in California. But what’s really in his power?
content: President Biden visited California this week to showcase his efforts to better protect the state against the raging wildfires that have burned more than two million acres, displaced thousands and pushed responders to the brink of exhaustion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Pentagon Asks Personnel to Report Any Symptoms of Mysterious Ailments
description: The episodes, known as Havana syndrome, have left spies, diplomats, soldiers and others with brain injuries.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is asking all military personnel, civilian officials and contractors to report any anomalous health episodes similar to the illnesses that have befallen diplomats and C.I.A. officers at the American Embassy in Havana, according to a new departmentwide message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Pauli Murray Should Be a Household Name. A New Film Shows Why.
description: The lawyer, activist and minister made prescient arguments on gender, race and equality that influenced Thurgood Marshall and Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: When the lawyer, activist, author and educator Pauli Murray died in 1985 at the age of 75, no obituary or commemoration could contain all of her pathbreaking accomplishments. A radical and brilliant legal strategist, Murray was named a deputy attorney general in California — the first Black person in that office — in 1946, just a year after passing the bar there. Murray was an organizer of sit-ins and participated in bus protests as far back as the 1940s, and co-founded the National Organization for Women. Murray was also the first Black woman to be ordained an Episcopal priest. In 2012, she was sainted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Newsom’s Anti-Trump Recall Strategy Offers Republicans a Warning for 2022
description: California Democrats were able to nationalize the vote — thanks to an avalanche of money, party discipline and, above all, an easily demonized opponent.
content: SAN LEANDRO, Calif. — California basks in its clairvoyance. “The future happens here first,” says Gov. Gavin Newsom, calling his state “America’s coming attraction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Abortion Has Never Been Just About Abortion
description: The way it became a “godsend” for the right is a peculiar tale.
content: As recently as 1984, abortion was not a deeply partisan issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in Scotland: A Unique Hybrid in the Highlands for $2.7 Million
description: The Highlands region, with its towering mountains and dramatic coastline, is seeing an ‘explosion of interest’ as more buyers leave cities.
content: This five-bedroom house, in the Arts and Crafts style with Swiss influences, sits on the banks of Loch Leven near the village of Ballachulish, in Scotland’s West Highlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Should Schools Require Students to Get the Coronavirus Vaccine?
description: Los Angeles became the first major school district to mandate vaccines for students 12 and older who are attending class in person. Should all school districts follow suit?
content: Were you required to receive certain vaccinations, such as those for protection against chickenpox or measles, before attending school or summer camp? Do you believe it is important for schools to require vaccinations like these to keep all students safe? Or do you think it should be up to individual families to decide?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: ‘Wicked’ returns with a surprise guest: Kristin Chenoweth.
description: The star, who originated the role of Glinda, helped welcome back the show, which has been seen by more than 60 million people in 100 cities around the world.
content: “Ladies and gentlemen,” a disembodied voice announced from the stage, bringing the crowd, which had gathered for the reopening of “Wicked,” to its feet: “Kristin Chenoweth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: What the exit polling tells us about the California electorate, and why it might be wrong.
description: The only exit poll from California’s recall election showed Gavin Newsom winning with an unusual coalition.
content: The only exit poll from California’s recall election showed Mr. Newsom winning with an unusual coalition. In a departure from nearly every recent election, longstanding racial and ethnic divides between white voters and voters of color seemed to vanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Walmart will test a self-driving delivery service with Ford and Argo.
description: The service will roll out in Miami, Washington and Austin, Texas, with a half dozen vehicles equipped with Argo’s technology.
content: Ford Motor and its autonomous driving affiliate, Argo AI, have teamed up with Walmart to begin testing the home delivery of groceries and other items by self-driving cars in three cities this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How did the Inspiration4 crew train for their flight?
description: Professional and amateur astronauts go through very similar training exercises.
content: SpaceX trained the Inspiration4 crew in largely the same way it has trained NASA crews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reeves Wiedeman
title: Why Does Every Company Now Want to Be a Platform?
description: In “The Platform Delusion,” Jonathan Knee takes apart the magical aura that surrounds one of Silicon Valley’s biggest conceptual exports.
content: THE PLATFORM DELUSIONWho Wins and Who Loses in the Age of Tech TitansBy Jonathan Knee
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: 8 Experiential Wedding Gifts
description: Experts share their best ideas for newlyweds who are craving something more interactive.
content: As the world slowly reopens after more than a year of Covid quarantine mandates, many brides and grooms are eager to get out of their homes, to try new things and to revisit pastimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Vaccine booster shots in the U.K.
content: As his popularity wanes, this time after a broken promise not to raise taxes, Boris Johnson has announced a vaccine campaign to offer booster shots to people 50 and older, as well as first shots to three million children, ages 12 to 15 — all while reiterating his vow to avoid future lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The Biden administration looks to expanded child care funds to combat labor shortages.
description: On Wednesday afternoon, Vice President Kamala Harris visited the Treasury Department to make the case for more child care funding.
content: The Biden administration is trying to build support for proposals to overhaul the nation’s rickety child care system as it pushes Congress to embrace a $3.5 trillion plan to expand social safety programs and looks for ways to combat ongoing labor shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: Ford’s Truck of the Future Looks Pretty Familiar
description: A compelling commercial to sell electric trucks leaves out planetary responsibility. Is this really good news?
content: A two-story house stands alone against a night sky. We’re watching from off in the distance, but the warm lights inside make it look cozy. Then a bolt of lightning shoots down from the sky. Thunder claps. The lights go out, plunging the home into darkness. Outside, a gray-haired man in a cowboy hat switches on a flashlight and stands next to his vintage pickup truck, surveying the property. Something is coming down the road. It’s another pickup truck. Close-up on the grille: It’s a Ford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Hypebeast Comes to the Luxury House
description: The streetwear veteran Nigo is named Kenzo’s first Japanese artistic director since 1999.
content: For the first time since the designer Kenzo Takada resigned from his namesake label Kenzo in 1999, a Japanese designer will once again run the Paris-based brand known for its multicultural ethos and energy. Nigo, one of the first of the streetwear superstars and an in-demand collaborator with multiple brands great and good, was named artistic director of the house on Wednesday by LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Kenzo’s parent company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How were the astronauts selected?
description: Jared Isaacman named the four Crew Dragon seats to reflect positive aspects of humanity.
content: For the mission, Mr. Isaacman named the four Crew Dragon seats to reflect positive aspects of humanity: leadership, hope, generosity and prosperity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iva Dixit
title: I Love Eating Raw Onions. Turns Out Many Readers Do, Too.
description: I wrote an appreciation. Or maybe it was a confession. Either way, I was surprised by the outpouring of comments.
content: Recently, with the self-annihilative bravado of a true fanatic, I wrote a 900-word encomium on the joys of eating red onions raw, in all their pungent, elemental glory, for the New York Times Magazine’s Letter of Recommendation column.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Congress pushes for a path to citizenship for ‘documented Dreamers.’
description: There is a growing bipartisan push to protect the children of nonimmigrant visa holders who were raised in the United States but cannot obtain green cards.
content: Senators introduced a bipartisan bill on Wednesday that would create a pathway to citizenship for some children and young adults who were raised in the United States but face deportation at age 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Hamilton’ draws giddy crowds on a festive night.
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda takes the stage and Al Roker revs up the crowd on a night of Broadway reopenings.
content: Kristin and Matt Collins, a couple from Annapolis, Md., were standing in line at the Richard Rodgers Theater on the reopening night of “Hamilton” with two extra tickets to give to anyone who wanted them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pope Rejects Political Use of Symbols of the Faith
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday September 15, 2021.
content: “The cross is not a flag to wave, but the pure source of a new way of living.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Best Stimulus Ever?
description: The share of people living in poverty in the U.S. fell to a record low last year, making the emergency pandemic aid look highly effective, if costly.
content: We are excited to announce the first in a series of DealBook Dialogue conference calls, which will feature industry experts taking your questions about the big issues of the day. Join us on Tuesday, Oct. 5, for a deep dive into cryptocurrency’s impact on the environment. Are the opportunities worth the costs? For more information and to R.S.V.P., free of charge, click here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jean-Claude van Itallie, ‘America Hurrah’ Playwright, Dies at 85
description: He was a central figure in the experimental theater movement for decades. His best-known work, a trilogy of one-acts, opened in 1966 and ran for more than 630 performances.
content: Jean-Claude van Itallie, a playwright, director and performer who was a mainstay of the experimental theater world and who was especially known for “America Hurrah,” a form-bending trio of one-acts that opened in 1966 in the East Village and ran for more than 630 performances, died on Sept. 9 in Manhattan. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Why Are We Still Going Great Guns?
description: The subject is guns. The password is safety.
content: Let’s take a look at how well Joe Biden is doing with his gun safety agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Deb
title: ‘They Are Manufacturing Foreigners’: How India Disenfranchises Muslims
description: Persecution in a remote Indian province spawned Modi’s new draconian citizenship law.
content: One November morning in 2015, a 37-year-old woman named Sahera Khatun received a notice summoning her to a foreigners’ tribunal. Sahera was living at the time in Sukharjar, a riverine village in the remote Indian state of Assam. She had moved there from Morabhaj, where she was born, after her marriage to a daily wage laborer named Amir. Sahera had given birth to five children in Sukharjar and seen nothing of the world beyond these two villages and the temperamental rivers that regularly inundate huts and farmland there. Yet the summons required her to prove that she was a citizen of India and not an illegal migrant from the neighboring country of Bangladesh. If she failed to make an appearance, the tribunal would declare her a foreigner and arrest her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Law Roach, a Stylist Whose Best Creation Is Himself
description: The self-described “image architect” was an M.V.P. of both New York Fashion Week and the Met Gala.
content: “Can you see how long it’s going to take me to get there,” the celebrity stylist Law Roach asked his publicist Sunday night, while seated in the bathroom at the Mark Hotel on New York’s Upper East Side, getting a touch-up in advance of the Tom Ford show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Federal regulators publish the first analysis of Pfizer’s booster shot application.
description: It comes two days before an outside advisory committee of experts is scheduled to meet to recommend whether or not the agency should approve the company’s request.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday offered the first public look at Pfizer’s application for a booster coronavirus shot, two days before an outside advisory committee of experts is scheduled to meet to recommend whether or not the agency should approve the company’s request.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: As G.O.P. Digs In on Debt Ceiling, Democrats Try Shaming McConnell
description: Senator Mitch McConnell says Republicans will not support raising the federal borrowing limit. Weeks before a potential default, Democrats do not appear to have a strategy for doing so.
content: WASHINGTON — With the government’s full faith and credit on the line, the Democratic leadership’s strategy for raising the federal borrowing limit seems to be this: Try to shame the impervious Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, into capitulating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Jaap van Zweden to Step Down as New York Philharmonic’s Maestro
description: Citing a reassessment of his priorities during the pandemic, the conductor will leave his post after the 2023-24 season.
content: Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s hard-charging music director, announced on Wednesday that he would leave his post at the end of the 2023-24 season, saying that the pandemic had made him rethink his life and priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Rhinebeck, N.Y.: A Historic Community With Cultural Amenities
description: With young families moving in, the Dutchess County town and the village at its center are increasingly lively — and increasingly pricey.
content: Gary Bassett moved to Rhinebeck, N.Y., in 1993, after being transferred by his employer, IBM, from Wisconsin to a plant in nearby Kingston. The village of about 2,600 residents in the Hudson Valley reminded him and his wife, Brenda Bassett, of their small hometown in central Pennsylvania, and they felt an immediate kinship with the place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Asks Judge to Block Texas’ Restrictive Abortion Law
description: The department sued Texas last week over its recently enacted law, which prohibits nearly all abortions in the state.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department asked a federal judge late Tuesday to issue an order that would prevent Texas from enforcing a law that prohibits nearly all abortions, ratcheting up a fight between the Biden administration and the state’s Republican leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘He Just Cried for a While.’ This Is My Reality of Parenting During a Climate Disaster.
description: One New Orleans mother on Hurricane Ida and what comes next.
content: Two days before Hurricane Ida made landfall in Louisiana in late August, Sarah DeBacher was trying to get her kids to stop dawdling and start packing. She needed them to understand the urgency of why they had to evacuate their home in Holy Cross, a neighborhood in the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto
title: The U.S. makes coronavirus vaccinations mandatory for new immigrants.
description: The Covid vaccine joins a list of others that applicants must have, including inoculations against measles, mumps, rubella, polio, and hepatitis A and B, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
content: Beginning Oct. 1, new immigrants to the United States must be fully vaccinated against Covid-19, the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services said in a news release on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Janet Yellen urges House Democrats to give the I.R.S. more power to crack down on tax evasion.
description: The Treasury secretary urged lawmakers not to water down a central piece of the budget plan, which would give the Internal Revenue Service visibility into the financial accounts of taxpayers.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen is pressing Representative Richard Neal, the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, to include the Biden administration’s full proposal for bolstering the Internal Revenue Service in its $3.5 trillion spending package, arguing that more resources and greater powers to catch tax evaders are crucial for reducing the “tax gap.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Soraya Shockley, Rob Szypko, Chelsea Daniel, Michael Simon Johnson, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Mexico’s Path to Legalizing Abortion
description: A landmark Supreme Court ruling in the country has decriminalized the procedure, but will changing the law also change attitudes?
content: In a major turn of events in Mexico, which has one of the largest Catholic populations in the world, its Supreme Court last week decriminalized abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: How Ibrahim Kamara Found His Place in Fashion
description: After a journey that began on the war-torn streets of Sierra Leone, the Dazed editor in chief is now one of fashion’s most influential stylists.
content: Ibrahim Kamara was sitting in a steamy hotel room in West Africa not long ago, reflecting on a fleeting visit to Gambia, a country he once called home. Born in Sierra Leone in 1990, Mr. Kamara fled to nearby Gambia after civil war broke out, spending much of his childhood with an aunt and uncle before settling in London with his parents at 16.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey and Raphael Minder
title: In Bid to End Secession Dispute, Spain Tries Talking with Catalonia
description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain met with the leader of Catalonia in an attempt to resolve the fate of the region.
content: MADRID — Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain on Wednesday held a long-awaited meeting with his regional counterpart in Catalonia to seek an end to Spain’s territorial conflict, four years after a failed Catalan secession attempt and 18 months after a first round of negotiations was abruptly curtailed by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: FEMA agrees to cover Covid-19 costs for NYC public hospitals.
description: The agency increased its contribution after an initial decision to reimburse only $260 million of the health system’s request for nearly $900 million.
content: After months of delay, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has agreed to reimburse New York City’s public hospital system almost $1 billion for its expenses treating patients during the city’s brutal first wave of Covid-19 in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: How One Principal Got Students Back to a Bronx Public School
description: Last year, 80 percent of students at Public School 5 and half its teachers learned and taught remotely.
content: Danielle Keane, the principal of Public School 5 in the South Bronx, spent months preparing for Monday morning, the first day of school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Here are some coping mechanisms for return-to-work anxiety.
description: The Delta variant and breakthrough infections have complicated plans for a smooth return to the physical workplace, reigniting concerns over safety, even among vaccinated workers.
content: The Delta variant and breakthrough infections have complicated plans for a smooth return to the physical workplace, reigniting concerns over safety, even among vaccinated workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Biden expresses confidence in Milley amid questions about his calls to China.
description: A new book alleges that Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, secretly called China over concerns that President Donald J. Trump might start a war.
content: WASHINGTON — The senior-most U.S. military officer did not bypass his civilian leaders when he called his Chinese counterpart in October and January, his office said on Wednesday after the release of excerpts from a new book that alleges that the conversations centered on concerns about President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: A.O.C.’s Met Gala Dress Triggered Strong Reactions
description: While some championed the provocation, the congresswoman’s “Tax the Rich” gown drew sharp statements from across the political spectrum.
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York arrived at the Met Gala on Monday evening dressed in a custom Brother Vellies ivory wool jacket dress with an organza flounce and the message “Tax the Rich” emblazoned in red across her back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Tiffany Hsu
title: The N.F.L.’s New Play: Embrace Betting Ads, Watch the Money Pour In
description: The placement of gambling ads during football game broadcasts shows how much the N.F.L. has changed in its approach toward gambling.
content: Betting has long been a part of the National Football League’s DNA. Two of its founding fathers, Art Rooney and Tim Mara, were gamblers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By N. Gregory Mankiw
title: Can America Afford to Become a Major Social Welfare State?
description: Biden's $3.5 trillion spending plan raises larger questions about the kind of nation we want to be.
content: In the reconciliation package now being debated in Washington, President Biden and many congressional Democrats aim to expand the size and scope of government substantially. Americans should be wary of their plans — not only because of the sizable budgetary cost but also because of the broader risks to economic prosperity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How much was spent on the recall? One estimate: Nearly half a billion dollars.
description: In adding up the recall’s price tag, including state costs and campaign spending, a Sonoma State University professor said the total was at least $450 million.
content: The recall election is over, and Gov. Gavin Newsom held onto his office, leaving many Californians to ask: So how much did this whole thing cost?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Back to School, for Now
description: Some seasonal constants (and variables).
content: Welcome. We’re closing in on bean season, root vegetable and apple cider season, at least here in the Northeastern United States. The greenmarket signifiers of fall are comforting, like the changing leaves and the changing light: seasonal constants on a planet where nothing’s seemed sure for quite some time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Booster Shots, California, Halle Berry: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: One of two Canadian railroads bidding for Kansas City Southern drops out.
description: Canadian Pacific was the winner to acquire Kansas City Southern after a merger agreement with Canadian National was terminated.
content: Canadian Pacific has emerged as the winner in a long-running battle to acquire Kansas City Southern, putting it in position to become the first railroad operator whose network extends from Canada to Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: There’s a Reason Why You Overshare on Dates
description: Sometimes it’s hard to stop talking when you’re nervous. There’s a name for that — and some tips to help.
content: Sam McRae was recently on a second date with a woman he’d met online. Over lunch at a Mexican restaurant, the Atlanta-based attorney could feel the date going off the rails. When the woman asked where Mr. McRae’s brother lived, he gave her a detailed account of his family’s dynamics. When she inquired about his job, he unloaded about how the pandemic tanked his business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle V. Agins and Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
title: A Simple Directive Sparked a Storied Career: ‘Now, Take the Picture.’
description: A new retrospective honors Michelle V. Agins, a Pulitzer-winning New York Times photographer who captures stories that would otherwise go untold.
content: Michelle V. Agins was only a child when she caught a murder on camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Slogans Don’t Save Lives
description: America needs safer streets, not empty slogans.
content: In Harlem last Sunday, a woman named Shanice Young was returning from her baby shower when she was shot in the head, allegedly by her ex-boyfriend. The ex was apparently looking to confront her current boyfriend when, instead, he shot her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Police in Aurora, Colo., Engaged in Racially Biased Policing, Inquiry Finds
description: The investigation by the Colorado Department of Law began after the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young Black man who was stopped by the police, put into a chokehold and injected with a powerful anesthetic.
content: The Police Department in Aurora, Colo., engaged in a pattern of racially biased policing and excessive force, according to an investigation that began after the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young Black man who was stopped by the police, put into a chokehold and injected with a powerful anesthetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Who are the other crew members?
description: In addition to Jared Isaacman, the mission's commander, there are three other astronauts aboard the Crew Dragon capsule.
content: In addition to Jared Isaacman, the mission’s commander, there are three more astronauts aboard the flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Alex Murdaugh Told His Former Client to Kill Him Before Shooting, Police Say
description: The former client was arrested after Mr. Murdaugh survived being shot in the head on a rural South Carolina road. Mr. Murdaugh’s wife and son had been fatally shot in June.
content: Alex Murdaugh, the prominent South Carolina lawyer whose wife and son were shot and killed in June, asked a former client to kill him this month so his other son could collect a $10 million insurance payment but survived being shot in the head, the police said on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Norm Macdonald’s Best Late-Night Moments
description: Macdonald was one of late-night TV’s funniest and most unpredictable guests. Here are clips from some of his most memorable appearances.
content: Norm Macdonald was best known for his stand-up comedy and his time as the Weekend Update anchor on “Saturday Night Live.” But the comic, who died on Tuesday at 61, was also hailed over the years for his hilariously unpredictable appearances on late-night shows, with several hosts on Tuesday remembering him as one of their funniest guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Elsie Chen
title: China #MeToo Figure Vows to Appeal After Losing Landmark Case
description: Zhou Xiaoxuan, a former television intern, became a leading voice in the movement after accusing a star presenter of assault.
content: A former television intern who became a prominent voice in China’s #MeToo movement against sexual assault and harassment has vowed to fight on after a court in Beijing ruled that she had not produced sufficient evidence in her harassment case against a star presenter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Bolsonaro’s Ban on Removing Social Media Posts Is Overturned in Brazil
description: President Jair Bolsonaro had issued rules forbidding social networks from removing many posts that the sites considered misinformation. On Tuesday, Brazil’s Senate and top court killed the policy.
content: The Brazil Senate and Supreme Court have nullified rules that President Jair Bolsonaro issued last week banning social networks from removing what they judge to be disinformation about the coming presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $1 Million Homes in Maine, Oregon and Connecticut
description: A reconstructed 1820 house in Camden, a one-bedroom condo in a converted warehouse in Portland and a 1910 home in New Haven.
content: This property was the caretaker’s cottage for the Mountain Arrow estate. In 2008, the main house of the estate was moved to the back of the property, and the rest of the land was developed into 13 lots. Several lots are now occupied by recently built historic-looking shingled houses surrounded by stone walls, and one lot contains this almost-studs-out reconstruction of an existing center-chimney building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Why is St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital involved?
description: The Inspiration4 launch is helping to raise money for the hospital, which helps treat pediatric cancer.
content: When he announced Inspiration4 in February, Mr. Isaacman said he wanted it to be more than an extraterrestrial jaunt for rich people like him. He reached out to St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis, which treats children at no charge and develops cures for childhood cancers as well as other diseases. Mr. Isaacman offered to use the mission as a fund-raising vehicle for St. Jude, setting a $200 million target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Latest Threat to Hong Kong’s National Security: Chocolates in Prison
description: Officials have suggested that imprisoned pro-democracy activists are using sweets and other items to “solicit followers” behind bars.
content: HONG KONG — As Hong Kong’s crackdown on dissent has intensified over the past year, the authorities have singled out myriad acts and items that they say could threaten national security. Mass protests. Informal elections. Chanting slogans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina F. Ichikawa
title: Looking for a Gold-Rush Town Named Chinese Camp
description: A writer went searching for Asian American history in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, where thousands of Chinese immigrants labored during the Gold Rush but where traces of their presence are few.
content: Four aging horses dragged us through the manzanita and boulders, the stagecoach swerving dangerously with each bump and wiggle. The children shrieked with excitement as we threaded our way through Columbia State Historic Park, a mining camp from the days of the Gold Rush about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Oakland, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Here’s Why Norm Macdonald Was Comedy Royalty. It’s Not ‘S.N.L.’
description: He may have been best known for his work on “Saturday Night Live,” but he should be really remembered for decades of club sets and you-can’t-miss-this clips.
content: My favorite Norm Macdonald joke — and trust me, there’s serious competition — is one he told as anchor of Weekend Update on “Saturday Night Live” in the late 1990s. Papers in front of him, he reported with a cheer: “Yippie! Jerry Rubin died this week.” Looking down, he apologized for his mistake and tried again: “That should read: ‘Yippie Jerry Rubin died this week.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Bolsonaro Is Getting Desperate, and It’s Clear What He Wants
description: His totalitarian aims are now unmistakable.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For weeks, President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has been urging his supporters to take to the streets. So on Sept. 7, Brazil’s Independence Day, I was half expecting to see mobs of armed people in yellow-and-green jerseys, some of them wearing furry hats and horns, storming the Supreme Court building — our very own imitation of the Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: American Football: Our Problematic Unifier
description: It is giving players brain damage. Is it time to stop watching?
content: It’s the start of another N.F.L. season, the time of year Americans turn on their televisions to watch their favorite teams make spectacular plays and their favorite players commit incredible acts of athleticism. But is America’s favorite pastime actually its guiltiest pleasure? Can fans ethically enjoy watching a football game?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Books on Race Filled Best-Seller Lists Last Year. Publishers Took Notice.
description: Titles that the houses signed in 2020 are now entering the world, with authors, agents and editors anxious to see how they do.
content: After George Floyd was murdered last May, and protests demanding racial justice swelled around the United States, bookstores had trouble keeping “So You Want to Talk About Race” by Ijeoma Oluo in stock. They couldn’t keep “White Fragility” by Robin DiAngelo or “The New Jim Crow,” a 2010 book by Michelle Alexander, on shelves either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Could Navalny’s ‘Smart Voting’ Strategy Shake Up Russia’s Election?
description: Five of the opposition leader’s exiled allies are engineering an election campaign that they hope will put dozens of Kremlin opponents into Parliament.
content: MOSCOW — In an undisclosed location outside Russia, five people have been meeting regularly for months to plot out how to deliver an improbable blow to President Vladimir V. Putin in this weekend’s Russian election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aanya Wipulasena and Mujib Mashal
title: Sri Lankan Minister Accused of Abusing Political Prisoners Resigns
description: Claims that the minister in charge of prison affairs had barged into jail while drunk and forced Tamil inmates to kneel at gunpoint come amid U.N. discussions on the country’s human rights record.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — A senior official in Sri Lanka accused of barging into prisons and abusing political prisoners just as the island nation’s government was downplaying concerns about worsening human rights conditions resigned on Wednesday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Warning at Rikers on the Anniversary of a Deadly Prison Uprising
description: The city’s public advocate warned that a debacle like the revolt at the Attica prison in 1971 could play out at Rikers, and soon.
content: It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at the legacy of the Attica prison uprising, which ended 50 years ago this week with an armed assault ordered by then-Gov. Nelson Rockefeller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: A vaccine mandate goes into effect for French health workers, but some are holding out.
description: As a coronavirus vaccination mandate for health workers went into effect in France on Wednesday, government officials said that some were still holding out against the obligation.
content: As a coronavirus vaccination mandate for health workers went into effect in France on Wednesday, government officials said that some were still holding out against the obligation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Johanna Burton Is Designated to Lead Los Angeles Museum
description: The contemporary art museum had split its directorial duties into two jobs but has made a quick about-face with Klaus Biesenbach’s departure.
content: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that Johanna Burton will become the institution’s sole director and the first woman in that role, now that Klaus Biesenbach has announced he will leave for Berlin to run the Neue Nationalgalerie and the adjacent Museum of the 20th Century, which is under development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Boston Mayor’s Race Narrows to a Progressive Versus a Moderate
description: The city’s 91-year succession of Irish American and Italian American mayors has ended, with Michelle Wu and Annissa Essaibi George facing off in November.
content: BOSTON — Michelle Wu, an Asian American progressive who has built a campaign around climate change and housing policy, sailed to a first-place finish in Boston’s preliminary mayoral election on Tuesday, winning 33 percent of the vote in a city that for nearly 200 years has elected only white men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: The Rich History of Black Westerns Enters a New Era
description: The genre dates back decades, when the films were made for segregated audiences. “The Harder They Fall” nods to the past but takes a new attitude altogether.
content: The upcoming Netflix western “The Harder They Fall” chronicles a blood feud between the Nat Love Gang and the Rufus Buck Gang. As in many westerns, the dueling outlaws hold deep grudges. They live outside polite society. They shoot first and occasionally get around to asking questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Endless Catastrophe of Rikers Island
description: The mayor promised to close the jail years ago, but the situation there is as desperate as it’s ever been.
content: Countless words have been written over the years, many by this board, illustrating the barbarity of the jail complex at Rikers Island and demanding its closure. The latest entry came this week, in a tweet thread by a New York State assemblywoman, Emily Gallagher, who attended a tour for elected officials and left in shock, calling the facility “a humanitarian crisis” and “a horror house of abuse and neglect.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Let Us Now Praise Tiny Ants’
description: Ants are everywhere. But how often do we stop to really notice them? In this lesson, students will learn about one of our smallest neighbors and reconsider what we know and how we feel about them.
content: Featured Article: “Let Us Now Praise Tiny Ants” by Brooke Jarvis, photographs by Eduard Florin Niga
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: California will reopen many of its national forests, but fire threats remain.
description: More firefighters and the end of summer tourist season were among the reasons the U.S. Forest Service cited in announcing the reopenings.
content: In a sign of improving weather and fire conditions in much of California, all but five of the state’s 20 national forests will reopen late Wednesday after they were closed to all visitors for 15 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Halle Berry’s Fight for the Director’s Chair
description: In many ways, her new film “Bruised” lets her assert control over how she appears onscreen. But first she had to win the job.
content: Halle Berry, in some form or another, has been fighting her whole life. Be it for coveted movie roles, on behalf of victims of domestic violence like herself, or against a perception that her physical beauty has insulated her from struggle, she has always seen herself as an underdog. And now, in her first film as a director, she has cast herself as one, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Zachary Woolfe
title: Fashion Returns to the Museum
description: With “In America” at the Met and “Christian Dior” at the Brooklyn Museum, our critics debate the nuances of showing fashion in art institutions, and find a depth of influence among young American designers.
content: It may be a simple coincidence that the Brooklyn Museum unveiled a major Dior extravaganza, “Christian Dior: Designer of Dreams,” the week before the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute opens its fall show, “In America: A Lexicon of Fashion.” But after two years of lockdowns and sweatpants, it seemed like fate. A fashion horn of plenty!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: Wednesday’s flight schedule
description: The launch could occur as early as 8:02 p.m. But the action will begin hours before that.
content: The launch could occur as early as 8:02 p.m. But the action will begin hours before that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden meets with executives to push vaccine mandates.
description: The meeting was intended to rally more support from business leaders, a White House official said.
content: President Biden met on Wednesday with top executives from Microsoft, the Walt Disney Company, Kaiser Permanente and other companies that have endorsed vaccine mandates, days after he announced a federal effort to require employees of large companies to be vaccinated against the coronavirus or be tested regularly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
title: Basking in Vaccine Success, E.U. Promises to Donate More Covid Shots
description: In an annual speech on the state of the bloc, Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, praised its coronavirus response but warned against a “pandemic of the unvaccinated.”
content: BRUSSELS — As Europeans try to lock in gains made by inoculation campaigns, the European Union on Wednesday pledged to reinforce its preparedness for future health crises and to increase coronavirus vaccine donations to low- and middle-income countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Remembers Norm Macdonald
description: Seth Meyers, James Corden and Jimmy Fallon paid tribute to the stand-up comic and former “Saturday Night Live” cast member on Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: L.A. County will require proof of vaccination at drinking establishments.
description: The county’s move reflects a wider shift in how far governments want to go in restricting the life of the unvaccinated.
